title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that in 2008, there were millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the U.S. originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively. The United States cocaine and heroin supply mainly originates from Andean countries like Bolivia, Colombia, and Peru, as well as Colombia and Mexico, respectively. This cultivation and trafficking in these countries lead to violence, instability, and corruption. Drug trafficking in transit countries like Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, and the Caribbean fuels organized crime and poses a threat to law enforcement. Drug trafficking of cocaine and heroin in Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and other Caribbean countries fuels organized crime, threatening law enforcement, political institutions, citizen security, and US interests. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in Mexico in 2008 alone. Drug-related violence is escalating in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in Mexico in 2008 alone. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the United States for sexual exploitation. In 2008, Mexico saw a significant increase in drug-related violence, with 5,661 deaths, more than double the previous year. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the United States for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to finance terrorist activities. United States provided $11.3 billion in counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean from 1980-2008. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, focusing on international drug policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify options to improve existing counternarcotics policies. The Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction, focusing on international drug control policies in the Western Hemisphere. Topics include drug interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives to illicit drugs, as well as the impact of the Andean Counterdrug Initiative (ACI). An assessment of US international illicit drug control policies in the Western Hemisphere, including drug interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives. Evaluation of the impact of initiatives like the Andean Counterdrug Initiative, Merida Initiative, and Caribbean Basin Security Initiative on curbing drug production, trafficking, and violence. Assessment of utilizing technology to target major drug cartels effectively. An assessment of US international illicit drug control policies in the Western Hemisphere, including efforts to curb drug production, trafficking, and violence. Evaluation of technology deployment against major drug cartels and trafficking of chemical precursors. Assessment of the US drug certification process and its alignment with international drug control policies. An assessment of the United States drug certification process and its alignment with international illicit drug control policies, including the evaluation of technology deployment against major drug cartels and trafficking of chemical precursors. Additionally, an assessment of the nature and extent of the United States population's demand for illicit drugs, as well as the effectiveness of drug prevention and treatment programs in the country. An assessment of the United States population's demand for illicit drugs and the effectiveness of drug prevention and treatment programs, including anti-drug coalitions, drug courts, and programs for preventing recidivism. Recommendations for improving these programs in the United States. The demand for illicit drugs in the United States is driven by addiction and abuse. Recommendations are made to improve policies aimed at reducing supply and demand, as well as supporting efforts in other countries to combat illicit drug use. The Commission will assess the value of supporting government and nongovernmental institutions in the Western Hemisphere to reduce illicit drug supply and demand, and evaluate the indicators of success in US drug control policy. Coordination with governments, international organizations, and NGOs in the Western Hemisphere is required for the review. The Commission will consult with government, academic, and nongovernmental leaders, as well as international organizations in the Western Hemisphere, including the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission (CICAD), to assess the proper indicators of success in US illicit drug control policy. The Commission will consult with various leaders and the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission to assess changes for increased effectiveness. They must submit a report to the House of Representatives and Senate committees within 12 months of their first meeting. The Commission will consult with leaders and the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission to assess changes for increased effectiveness. They must submit a report to relevant House and Senate committees within 12 months of their first meeting. The Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives and the Senate, the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives and the Senate, the Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives and the Senate, along with key government officials, must submit a detailed report to relevant committees. The Committee on Armed Services, along with other key government officials, must submit a detailed report containing recommendations, findings, and conclusions to relevant committees. The report will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of ten members appointed by various leaders, with restrictions on including current government officials. Each member serves for the duration of the Commission's existence, with vacancies not affecting its power. The President appoints two members to the Commission, with restrictions on including current government officials. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies do not affect its power, and appointments must be made within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. The initial meeting and selection of the Chairperson must occur within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Members of the Commission are appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days, the Commission must hold an initial meeting to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule. Six members constitute a quorum, and members receive travel expenses. The Commission shall hold an initial meeting to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule for the review and report. Six members constitute a quorum, and members receive travel expenses according to specified regulations. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold meetings, conduct hearings, and access necessary resources from various government departments to fulfill its duties. The Commission has the authority to access resources from government departments such as the Library of Congress, Department of State, Department of Health and Human Services, and others. The Chairperson can request access in writing, and the General Services Administration provides office space for Commission activities and meetings. The Commission has the authority to access resources from government departments and agencies. The General Services Administration provides office space and administrative support for Commission activities. The Commission can use the United States mails like other government departments. The Commission, with the support of the General Services Administration, can access resources from government departments and agencies. It has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts for necessary activities. The Commission is authorized to enter into contracts with various entities for activities necessary to fulfill its duties, with contracts not extending beyond the Commission's termination date. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may appoint additional personnel without following standard appointment procedures. The Commission may appoint necessary personnel without following standard appointment procedures, with compensation not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Experts and consultants can be hired with Commission approval. The Executive Director can hire temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, US Code, and Federal agencies can detail personnel to the Commission without reimbursement. The Executive Director can procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, US Code, and Federal agencies can detail personnel to the Commission to assist in its duties without affecting their civil service status or privileges. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission without fiscal year limitation. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission to Congress.
